title-group.subtitle: Evidence From Measures of the Five-Factor Model, UPPS Model of Impulsivity, and BIS/BAS

author-notes.corresp: Joshua D. Miller, Department of Psychology, University of Georgia, Athens, GA 30602-3013, USA Email: jdmiller@uga.edu

abstract.p: Although many studies of personality and aggression focus on multidimensional traits and higher order personality disorders (e.g., psychopathy), lower order, unidimensional traits may provide more precision in identifying specific aspects of personality that relate to aggression. The current study includes a comprehensive measurement of lower order personality traits in relation to three forms of aggression: reactive, proactive, and relational. Traits related to interpersonal antagonism and impulsivity, especially impulsive behavior in the context of negative affect, were consistently related to aggression across multiple indices. These findings suggest that certain lower order traits are of critical importance to understanding who engages in aggressive behavior and why this behavior occurs.

body.p: Seeking to identify a reliable trait-based set of predictors for aggression, researchers have often focused on personality constructs such as psychopathy and narcissism. Psychopathy is a personality disorder characterized by traits such as callousness, manipulativeness, egocentricity, impulsivity, and a need for stimulation (e.g., Cleckley, 1941; Hare, 2003) as well as a history of early, pervasive antisocial behavior. It is related to criminality and aggression (Gretton, Hare, & Catchpole, 2004; Skeem & Mulvey, 2001) and is a significant predictor of general and violent recidivism (Hemphill, Hare, & Wong, 1998). Narcissism and its personality disorder variant—narcissistic personality disorder—comprise traits such as egocentricity, grandiosity, deficient empathy, and entitlement. Like psychopathy, narcissistic traits have been related to both self-reported aggression and aggression manifested in laboratory-based paradigms (e.g., Bushman & Baumeister, 1998; Maples et al., 2010).

To understand better the relations between personality and aggression, we believe it may be advantageous to focus on lower order, unidimensional personality constructs, many of which are included in larger models of personality such as the Five-Factor Model (FFM), BIS/BAS (behavioral inhibition system/behavioral activation system), and models of impulsivity. One advantage of this approach is that it allows for a clearer delineation of the manner in which personality predicts/correlates with aggression. That is, although it is useful to demonstrate that certain personality disorders (e.g., psychopathy) are related to aggression, it does not explain which of the underlying traits are most relevant to aggression. For example, numerous studies have demonstrated that psychopathy can be understood as low levels of interpersonal agreeableness and conscientiousness and a mixture of high and low scores on the traits of neuroticism and extraversion (e.g., Lynam & Widiger, 2007; Miller, Lynam, Widiger, & Leukefeld, 2001). By using these lower order dimensions, one can examine which factors are most salient to the understanding of aggression. The use of these lower order dimensions is also important as studies have demonstrated that lower order, narrow facets are better predictors of behavior than the higher order domains (e.g., Paunonen & Ashton, 2001).

A number of studies have examined the personality correlates of externalizing behaviors in general (e.g., substance use, antisocial behavior; Krueger, Markon, Patrick, Benning, & Kramer, 2007) and aggression more specifically (e.g., Bettencourt, Talley, Benjamin, & Valentine, 2006; Miller & Lynam, 2006; Seibert, Miller, Pryor, Reidy, & Zeichner, 2010). Overall, externalizing behaviors appear to be most strongly correlated with traits related to interpersonal antagonism and poor impulse control, followed by heightened negative emotionality (e.g., Miller & Lynam, 2001) and this may be the case for aggression as well (e.g., Miller & Lynam, 2006; Seibert et al., 2010).

From our vantage point, there are three limitations in the extant literature regarding the relations between personality traits and aggression. First, many of these studies have examined a limited number of personality constructs and/or personality models. This is unfortunate as there are some data to support the importance of less frequently used but potentially relevant constructs such as traits related to behavioral activation/behavioral inhibition (e.g., Seibert et al., 2010). Second, although impulsivity is related to externalizing behaviors and aggression, recent conceptual and empirical work suggests that impulsivity should be conceived of as a multidimensional construct (e.g., Whiteside & Lynam, 2001) and that these various “impulsivity-facets” may be differentially related to aggression. Third, most of this literature has examined aggression using a single form of aggression (vs. examining different variants of aggression). This is unfortunate as it is possible that the traits most relevant to aggression may differ depending on these factors. For instance, reactive and proactive aggression appear to differ substantially with regard to the role of trait neuroticism (i.e., tendency to experience negative emotions such as depression, anger, shame, and anxiety) such that individuals who engage in reactive aggression (i.e., behaving aggressively as a reaction to frustration) are more likely to have higher trait levels of neuroticism than individuals who are more likely to engage in more proactive or instrumental aggression (i.e., behaving aggressively in the service of achieving a desired outcome; e.g., Miller & Lynam, 2006). Even less work has examined which traits are most strongly related to relational aggression, which is defined as behaving in a manner so as to intentionally damage another individual’s social standing among and relationships with peers.

In the current study, we examined the relations between personality and aggression using three prominent measures of personality (i.e., Revised NEO Personality Inventory (NEO PI-R); UPPS-P Impulsive Behavior scale, BIS/BAS), and three forms of self-report aggression (i.e., reactive, proactive, relational). The three personality measures were chosen to provide a comprehensive assessment of three different models of personality that vary substantially in breadth. The NEO PIR is measure of the Five-Factor Model (FFM) of personality, which is considered to be a relatively all encompassing model of personality in that it is thought to include all major domains of personality. The UPPS-P is a multidimensional measure of impulsivity (U = Urgency; P = Lack of Perseverance; P = Lack of Premeditation; S = Sensation Seeking; P = Positive Urgency) that assesses disinhibited/risky behavior from five different trait pathways (e.g., emotional dysregulation; excitement seeking; failure to consider consequences). Finally, the measure of behavioral activation/inhibition system (BIS/BAS) is derived from a theoretical model of motivation that posits the existence of two major behavioral systems that result in differing means of interacting with and reacting to environmental stimuli.

We expected that traits related to interpersonal antagonism (e.g., NEO PI-R Agreeableness) and impulsivity (NEO PI-R Conscientiousness; UPPS-P dimensions) would be among the most consistent correlates of all forms of aggression (e.g., Miller & Lynam, 2001; Miller, Lynam, & Leukefeld, 2003). Alternatively, we expected traits related to negative emotionality (NEO PI-R Neuroticism; UPPS-P Negative Urgency) to correlate primarily with reactive forms of aggression (e.g., Bettencourt et al., 2006; Miller & Lynam, 2006).

sec.title: Participants and Procedure
sec.p: Participants were 116 undergraduate men and women (56% male; mean age = 19.16; SD = 1.27; 80.17% White) from introductory psychology classes at a large Southeastern university who chose to participate as part of a general research requirement for these classes. After providing informed consent, participants completed all self-report questionnaires followed by a laboratory task not included in the current study (the laboratory task was completed at a different date); on average the questionnaires usually took 2 hr to complete. Participants were debriefed at the completion of the study. IRB approval was obtained for this study.

sec.title: Revised NEO Personality Inventory (NEO-PI-R)
sec.p: The NEO PI-R (Costa & McCrae, 1992) is a 240-item self-report measure of the FFM. The higher order domains of the inventory include Neuroticism, Extraversion, Openness, Agreeableness, and Conscientiousness. The alphas for the domains ranged from .89 to .93. Alphas for the facets ranged from .53 to .86, with a median of .77

sec.title: UPPS-P Impulsive Behavior Scale (UPPS-P)
sec.p: The UPPS-P is a 59-item self-report measure of five traits believed to fall under the “umbrella” of impulsivity (Lynam, Smith, Whiteside, & Cyders, 2006). The Negative and Positive Urgency scales assess difficulties in resisting cravings and urges when in a negative or positive affective state. (Lack of) Perseverance measures the tendency to give up easily because of boredom, fatigue, or task difficulty. (Lack of) Premeditation assesses the tendency to fail to pause and deliberate before acting. Finally, Sensation Seeking measures the tendency to pursue activities that may be exciting, novel, or involve risk. In the current study, alphas ranged from .76 (Lack of Perseverance) to .94 (Positive Urgency).

sec.title: BIS/BAS scales
sec.p: Behavior inhibition (BIS) and activation systems (BAS) are assessed via 20 self-report questions (Carver & White, 1994). The BIS is assessed via seven items. The BAS is measured using three short subscales including Reward Responsiveness (five items) Drive (four items), and Fun Seeking (four items). In the current study, alphas ranged from .75 to .82.

sec.title: Reactive-Proactive Aggression Questionnaire
sec.p: This scale is composed of 23 items that assess reactive (M = 8.54; SD =3.68) and proactive (M = 2.16; SD = 2.50) aggression (Raine et al., 2006). Coefficient alphas for the reactive and proactive aggression scales were .79 and .76, respectively.

sec.title: Self-report measure of aggression and victimization
sec.p: Fifteen items were used to measure relational aggression (α = 88; M = 29.98; SD = 22.84; Morales & Crick, 1998). Content includes questions such as “I have spread rumors about a person just to be mean.” Previous studies have documented its correlations with other measures of aggression and relevant personality disorders (Schmeelk, Sylvers, & Lilienfeld, 2008).

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The correlations between the three aggression scores ranged from .50 (relational and reactive aggression) to .70 (relational and proactive aggression) with a median of .55.

sec.title: Relations Between NEO PI-R Traits and Aggression Indices
sec.p: Next, we examined the correlations among the 5 broad domains, 30 specific facets, and three aggression indices (see Table 1). To summarize these findings, we calculated mean effect sizes for these traits across the aggression scores. We first transformed the relevant correlations using a Fisher Z transformation, after which these scores were summed and averaged to create mean correlations. The average Fisher Z for each trait was then transformed back to a Pearson r. Across the aggression indices, Agreeableness was the most consistent correlate; the Agreeableness domain was significantly negatively correlated with all three aggression scores (mean r = –.42) and three individual facets manifested moderate effect sizes: Straightforwardness, Altruism, and Compliance. At the domain level, Conscientiousness (mean r = –.29) and Neuroticism (mean r = .27) manifested the next largest effect sizes of the remaining domains; within these domains each had one facet manifest a moderate effect size: Angry Hostility (from Neuroticism) and Deliberation (from Conscientiousness). None of the facets from Extraversion or Openness manifested a moderate mean effect size.

caption.p: Correlations Between FFM Traits and Aggression

fn.p: Note. Bold = mean effect size >.30; r = bivariate correlation; sr = semipartial correlation. FFM = Five-Factor Model.

sec.title: Relations Among UPPS-P, BIS/BAS, and Aggression Indices
sec.p: The UPPS-P impulsivity-related traits manifested a range of mean effect sizes with the aggression indices such that both Negative (mean r = .43) and Positive Urgency (mean r = .34) manifested the largest effect sizes (see Table 2), followed by lack of Perseverance (mean r = .24), lack of Premeditation (mean r = .15) and Sensation Seeking (mean r = .11). The BIS/BAS scales manifested limited significant correlations with the aggression indices (i.e., only 2 of 12 correlations were significant). The mean effect sizes for the four BIS/BAS scales ranged from .06 (BAS-Reward) to .17 (BAS-Fun Seeking).

caption.p: Correlations Between UPPS-P, BIS/BAS and Aggression

fn.p: Note. Bold = mean effect size >.30; r = bivariate correlation; sr = semipartial correlation. UPPS-P: U = Urgency; P = Lack of Perseverance; P = Lack of Premeditation; S = Sensation Seeking; P = Positive Urgency; BIS/BAS = behavioral inhibition system/behavioral activation system.

sec.title: Overall Pattern of Similarity
sec.p: To compare the trait profiles of the three aggression scores in a quantitative manner, we calculated similarity scores using intraclass correlations via double entry q-correlations (see McCrae, 2008 for a review) between the columns of correlations (e.g., correlations between reactive aggression and 44 traits of the FFM, UPPS, and BIS/BAS vs. correlations between proactive aggression and 44 traits of the FFM, UPPS, and BIS/BAS). All three aggression profiles were significantly related with strong correlations ranging between .80 (reactive and proactive aggression) and .87 (reactive and relational aggression).

sec.title: Unique Aggression-Trait Profiles
sec.p: Given that the three forms of aggression are significantly correlated and generate similar trait profiles, we next took steps to examine their unique trait profiles. We did this by regressing each aggression score on the other two aggression scores (e.g., reactive aggression regressed on proactive and relational aggression) and saved the residuals. We then correlated these residualized scores with the five domains from the FFM,1 the UPPS, and the BIS/BAS domains. From a trait perspective, the residualized reactive aggression scores were primarily correlated with traits related to negative emotionality (e.g., Neuroticism; Negative Urgency; BIS), whereas proactive aggression was uniquely related to impulsivity from the perspective of Conscientiousness. Finally, relational aggression was uniquely correlated both with BIS and BAS-Drive scores. None of the three residualized aggression scores manifested unique correlations with Agreeableness, reflecting its central role in all three forms of aggression.

sec.title: Predictive Utility of the Three Personality Models in Relation to Aggression
sec.p: Finally, we conducted a series of simultaneous regression analyses in which each aggression score was regressed on the domain scores from each of the personality models (conducted individually; e.g., only one personality model was included at a time; see Table 3). To account for slightly different number of predictors, we compared the adjusted R-squared value. At the model level, the FFM domains accounted for the largest mean adjusted R-squared value (i.e., .28), followed by the UPPS-P model (i.e., .24), and BIS/BAS (i.e., .08). Across the models, FFM Agreeableness was the most consistent unique predictor of all forms of aggression. Across the forms of aggression, the greatest variance accounted for was by the UPPS-P model of impulsivity-related traits in relation to reactive aggression (i.e., .33).

caption.p: Simultaneous Regression Analyses Using Personality Models to Predict Aggression

fn.p: Note: FFM = Five-Factor Model; UPPS-P: U = Urgency; P = Lack of Perseverance; P = Lack of Premeditation; S = Sensation Seeking; P = Positive Urgency; BIS/BAS = behavioral inhibition system/behavioral activation system.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The current study represents one of the first attempts (cf. Seibert et al., 2010) to simultaneously examine multiple models of personality in the statistical prediction of various forms of aggression. Several personality traits were consistently related to aggression across the indices—these traits can be categorized as falling into one of two broader domains: interpersonal antagonism (e.g., low Straightforwardness, Altruism, Compliance) and impulsivity-related traits (low Deliberation, low Dutifulness, high Negative and Positive Urgency). The latter category is itself quite heterogeneous and the results suggest that both Conscientiousness-related forms of impulsivity (i.e., failing to think of the consequences before acting) and Neuroticism-related forms of impulsivity (i.e., acting impulsively when emotionally dysregulated) are significant correlates of aggression. These results are consistent with research documenting the critical role these types of traits play in the commission of externalizing behaviors of all types (Krueger et al., 2007) including antisocial behavior (Miller & Lynam, 2001) and aggression (Bettencourt et al., 2006). Some have argued that these traits may explain the comorbidity of these forms of behavior (Miller & Lynam, 2001). It is important to note that interpersonal antagonism is a central component of both psychopathy (along with impulsivity-related traits; e.g., Lynam & Derefinko, 2006) and narcissism (e.g., Miller & Campbell, 2008) and may help explain why these disorders are robust predictors of aggression.

Consistent with previous work of this nature (e.g., Miller & Lynam, 2006), the profile analyses conducted in the current study provided strong support for the generality of the traits most strongly correlated with aggressive behavior. Regardless of the form of aggression considered, the same general traits tended to be implicated as demonstrated by the intraclass correlations among the trait profiles (r iccs ranged from .80 to .87). These results, like the general pattern of correlations among the aggression measures, suggest that individuals who aggress in one manner (e.g., proactive) are likely to aggress in other ways as well (e.g., reactive). That is, individuals do not seem to “specialize” in one form of aggression to the exclusion of others. Alternatively, we also examined the unique trait profiles of each form of aggression by regressing each form of aggression on the other two forms of aggression and saving the residuals. As expected (Miller & Lynam, 2006), reactive aggression was uniquely related to traits indicative of emotion dysregulation, whereas proactive aggression was most strongly uniquely correlated with traits related to disinhibition. Finally, relational aggression did not manifest a particularly strong and clear unique pattern as it manifested unique significant positive correlations with both behavioral inhibition and activation.

The substantial role of traits related to Agreeableness in aggression, along with many of other externalizing behaviors, warrants greater attention as to the mechanisms that may explain these relations. Antagonistic individuals report feeling less sympathy and empathy toward others (Graziano, Habashi, Sheese, & Tobin, 2007), making it easier to cause others harm. Antagonistic individuals are also less able or willing to forgive others for their (real or perceived) transgressions (Strelan, 2007), which may increase the likelihood of using aggression to retaliate. In general, antagonism is linked to aggressive forms of social cognition/information processing such that antagonistic individuals are prone to hostile attribution biases and are more likely to access and choose aggressive responses versus using compromise or other more prosocial options (Jensen-Campbell & Graziano, 2001; Miller, Lynam, & Jones, 2008). The tendency for disagreeable individuals to view the world as being infused with threat and hostility may come from early experiences with trauma or victimization (Miller et al., 2010). For instance, among adolescents, antagonism increases the likelihood of being victimized by peers, which may set the stage for aggressive social information processing and reactive aggression (Jensen-Campbell et al., 2002).

Disagreeable individuals are also less able to effectively regulate both negative affect, particularly affect linked with aggression and conflict (e.g., Meier, Robinson, & Wilkowski, 2006; Ode & Robinson, 2009), and cognition (e.g., Jensen-Campbell et al., 2002), which may predispose individuals toward “acting out” behaviors. Antagonistic individuals also evince more difficulty disengaging their attention from antisocial stimuli (Meier et al., 2006; Wilkowski, Robinson, & Meier, 2006), which may increase their likelihood of engaging in aggression.

Traits related to impulsivity were also significantly related to aggressive behavior. As noted earlier, there seem to be multiple forms of impulsivity with some arguing that the term “impulsivity” represents “an artificial umbrella term that actually encompasses several distinct facets of personality associated with impulsive behavior” (Whiteside & Lynam, 2001, p. 687). In the current study, the results suggest that individuals who evince deficits in inhibiting impulses when affectively aroused and individuals who have a broader problem with inhibition were more likely to aggress. It is interesting to note that both impulsivity-related traits and aggressive behavior are associated with histories of abuse and maltreatment (e.g., Brodsky et al., 2001; Stouthamer-Loeber, Loeber, Homish, & Wei, 2001; Widom, Schuck, & White, 2006). Braquehais, Oquendo, Baca-García, and Sher (2010) suggest that childhood abuse “diminishes the capacity of the brain to inhibit negative actions and to control and modulate emotions” (p. 121). It is possible that the link between childhood abuse and later aggression is mediated, in part, by higher levels of disinhibition.

One beneficial aspect of understanding aggression from the perspective of personality is that it may help explain the etiology of aggression and pertinent changes that occur over time. At the level of neurotransmitters, aggression has been linked to lower levels of serotonin (see Seo, Patrick, & Kennealy, 2008, for a review). Interestingly, many of the trait correlates related to aggression are also believed linked with serotonin functioning. For instance, DeYoung, Peterson, Séguin, and Tremblay (2008) argue that the variance shared by Agreeableness (inversely), Conscientiousness (inversely), and Neuroticism (a higher order trait referred to as either “Alpha” (Digman, 1997) or “Stability” (DeYoung et al., 2008) is linked with serotoninergic functioning (e.g., Depue & Collins, 1999; Manuck et al., 1998). Increasing serotonin is known to reduce aggression in animals (Eichelman, 1990, 1993) and decrease quarrelsome behavior in humans (aan het Rot, Moskowitz, Pinard, & Young, 2006; Moskowitz, Pinard, Zuroff, Annable, & Young, 2001), which is linked to Agreeableness (Moskowitz, 2010). Moskowitz suggests that increased brain serotonin may lead to “changes in perception” (seeing others as more agreeable), “increased affective reactivity” (to behaving antagonistically toward others), and “decreased behavioral reactivity”—all changes that should decrease aggression.

sec.title: Limitations and Conclusions
sec.p: The current study examined aggressive behavior in a relatively small and homogenous sample composed primarily of White undergraduate students; as such, the generalizability of these findings should be tested in larger and more diverse samples. A recent meta-analytic review of the relations between the NEO PI-R and aggression found that the relations were moderated, to some degree, by sample type (Jones, Miller, & Lynam, 2011). For instance, the relations between traits related to conscientiousness and aggression appear to be stronger (more negative) in samples of undergraduates. In addition, because of the small nature of this sample, certain results were not significant that likely would have been in a sample with greater power (e.g., conscientiousness and relational aggression). Also, levels of aggression in the current sample were relatively limited and this restriction of range may have worked to limit the effect sizes found between the personality traits and aggression scores. Finally, the current results relied on self-reports of personality and aggression, which likely inflated the effect sizes due to shared method variance. This inflation is likely offset, however, by measurement error (cf. Lance, Dawson, Birkelbach, & Hoffman, 2010). One benefit of the use of undergraduate samples in studies such as these is that the participants are likely to have greater reading and comprehension skills (vs. community or forensic samples), skills which are vital to a study such as this that relies heavily on the participants’ abilities to understand an array of written materials. The current participants were asked to complete a number of different inventories so as to be able to test each personality model against one another and, thus, we needed participants with sufficiently high reading abilities and processing speed, which would enable them to complete all the questionnaires in a reasonable time frame.

In conclusion, the personality correlates of aggression are similar to those found for other externalizing behaviors. Traits related to interpersonal antagonism and disinhibition (generally and under conditions of negative affect) are relatively consistent correlates of aggressive behavior. It will be important to address these traits (e.g., via pharmaceutical or psychotherapeutic interventions) if society is to see substantial decrements in aggression and other related behaviors.

fn.label: Declaration of Conflicting Interests
fn.p: The authors declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: The authors received no financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

For the sake of parsimony, we report only the correlations between the five primary FFM domains the three residualized aggression scores. The full matrix is available from the first author on request.

bio.title: Bios
bio.p: Joshua D. Miller is an associate professor of psychology in the Psychology Department at the University of Georgia. His research interests include the study of personality traits and disorders related to externalizing behaviors such as crime, aggression, substance use, and risky sex.

Amos Zeichner is a professor of psychology and director of the Psychology Clinic in the Psychology Department at the University of Georgia. His research interests focus on human aggression, violence against sexual minorities, and effects of gender norm violation.

Lauren F. Wilson is a graduate student in the Clinical Training Program of the Department of Psychology at the University of Georgia. Her research interests include the interactive effects of antisocial behavior, personality, socialization factors, and attendant situational determinants.
